posts.name: Drew Williams
posts.cooked:
Hello CD,

Our team is working on improving our CAD workflow for this upcoming season. Last season we had one person working on their personal laptop with Inventor installed with Autodesk Vault for version control. This obviously doesn’t scale to have multiple students working simultaneously.

All the school pcs have Autodesk Inventor, but the school blocks the connection to our Vault server. The school IT department doesn’t want to set up a shared network drive for us to work off of…

The students have access to onshape on their pcs as well, but we really liked the CAM software inventor has. This would allow us to collaborate, but I am unsure if OnShape is capable enough for our needs. We have a CNC router, mill, and lathe and would like to generate GCode. Does OnShape offer this?

Any advice is appreciated!

Drew

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: I moved to California just for districts

posts.custom_user_title: I moved to California just for districts

posts.name: Smtopps
posts.cooked:
Right now we export step files and import them into fusion 360. I like fusions software which I found to be very intuitive but inconvenient.

Recently this announcement came from onshape but early 2023 could be after build season.

link_counts.title: PTC Brings Cloud-Native CAM to Onshape with CloudMilling Acquisition | PTC

posts.name: Parker Harris
posts.cooked: My team currently does the same thing, it’s not perfect and kinda inefficient to have to export step files, but in my experience it is much better than the current solutions in onshape like kiri:moto. Hopefully that announcement for onshape will be a better solution, but for now fusion 360 is the best that I have tried for FRC.

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked:
We also use Fusion360 for CAM, although fusion can import native SolidWorks files so we don’t need to export as steps.

That said, if you are already used to Autodesk software, using fusion for CAD and CAM might be the way to go, it already has shared projects built in.

posts.name: Breakaway3937
posts.cooked: We take the models and export them as Solidworks parts.  We got the HSMWorks embedded tool for Solidworks free from Autodesk .  It is a great tool and works well with our OMIO x8 router.

posts.name: Ethan Braun
posts.cooked: We currently import into Fusion 360, which works fine, but I wonder if there is a more time efficient workflow for just doing sheet metal on a router.

posts.name: Aidan Mundy
posts.cooked: Really running the gamut of CAD/CAM publishers… Autodesk, Dassault Systèmes, and PTC in one workflow

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
satel:

We currently import into Fusion 360, which works fine, but I wonder if there is a more time efficient workflow for just doing sheet metal on a router.

If you create templates in Fusion 360 with all the common router operations, it takes just a couple minutes to edit the needed operations for a part and select the paths to be cut.  Delete unneeded operations.  Fusion 360 with templates is extremely efficient, even if you have to start by exporting the parts from Onshape and opening them in Fusion.

Nice video introduction to templates .

link_counts.title: Fusion 360 — All About CAM Templates —Your Comments & Questions — #LarsLive 32 - YouTube

posts.name: Breakaway3937
posts.cooked: As mentioned by @Smtopps , hopefully, OnShape will have a good option in the coming year.  I have no way to even test out Cloudmilling as of right now as it doesn’t have a download or sign in option.

posts.name: Dan_Karol
posts.cooked: We CAD in Onshape and then export to inventor HSM, which is similar to Fusion or HSMWorks.  CAM  doesn’t need to be as version controlled as CAD does.

posts.name: Chadfrom7226
posts.cooked:
Fusion 360 on a single laptop for CAM

For sheetmetal: Onshape → Export DXF → Import to F360 sketch → Extrude → CAM

For Non-flat parts: Onshape → Export STEP → Upload to F360 → CAM

posts.name: Chadfrom7226
posts.cooked: If you do a lot of sheet metal like we do, familiarize yourself with templates. That will save you an enormous amount of time

posts.name: Smtopps
posts.cooked: I don’t know if anyone on CD works for onshape and reads this, but it would be nice if FRC teams could beta test it.

posts.name: Drew B.
posts.cooked: While I can’t promise beta testing, we do know that FRC is a prime use-case for Onshape’s integrated CAM!

posts.name: Nick Aarestad
posts.cooked: Honestly I’m just hoping it’s available, on any level, to standard Education accounts. Integrated CAM is probably the biggest real usecase of all the functionality PTC has been adding to Onshape via acquisitions and new development for FRC. I’d love simulation and rendering too, but they aren’t nearly as critical.

posts.name: Matt Brechting
posts.cooked: Anything you can tell us 8 months later

posts.name: Drew B.
posts.cooked:
Development and integration into Onshape is going well! I think early 2023 was an optimistic timeline but not too far off. If you want to see where it is currently and what it’ll mostly look like, this video contains a fair amount of demo time:

As soon as anything major happens, I’ll make sure to update here, as I know there are a lot of teams (mine included) that are ready for more information.

posts.name: David B
posts.cooked: We use onshape for CAD and got a Shapeoko CNC router at the start of the season and initially used kiri-moto for CAM.  We switched about half-way through the season to Carbide Create Pro which is 120$ per year and native to the Shapeoko CNC.  We are most likely sticking with it for the 2023 offseason into the 2024 season.

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: Our team uses onshape for robot cad and then we export parts to fusion to cam them for our cnc machines

posts.name: Gdeaver
posts.cooked:
We have been using Estlecam since 2017. We export to a DXF file for 2.5 D machining. Estlecam can import STL’s for 3 axis machining but we do not do any. 60$ for a 3 computer license. You can use it for free but after while the time to generate a G code file takes longer and longer. we use the native Estlecam format for 1 router that is driven by an Arduino. Estlecam can generate Mach 3 G code and we do this for our Omio 6. What I like about it is that it is very visual and the students pick it up quickly. 2 weeks ago I had a 7th grader going in 1 meeting.

estlcam.de
